g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
lie in development pathways that can maximize the synergies between climate mitigation and
change, employment generation and the performance of policy
instruments, such as green taxes, subsidies, emission permits, investments and finance. Short
term macroeconomic models have been used to assess the impacts of such policy instruments.

There is an emerging modelling literature focusing on the synergies and trade
development pathways and various aspects of sustainable development. The early literature, including
that on IAMs, and macroeconomic and sectoral models mainly focused on the co
policies in terms of reduced air p
ollution, energy security and to some extent employment generation

(Clarke et al. 2014; IPCC 2014, 2018; Kolstad et al. 2014)
here is a need to incorporate issues and enablers
varying forms of innovation, possibilities for behavioural
IAMs and macroeconomic models typically calculate mitigation costs based on the assumpti
markets internalise externalities like GHG emissions through carbon prices
. Yet, there are legitimate questions to
the models. How GHG emissions taxes would actually work is th
(Barker et al. 2016; Fontana and Sawyer 2016; Meyer et al. 2018)
limitations, the use of GHG emission taxes as an effective instrument based on modelling results
Despite the shortcomings of conventional economic thought and models
how mitigation costs can be as
For instance, while a conventional perspective might suggest that climate
costs can limit investments in sustainability because they reduce the productivity of capital by
increasing energy prices and the products in which energies are em
innovation can imply increases in efficiency and that the substitution of energy, material and labour can
lead to the accumulation of capital and productivity gains. This appears to occur with innovations in
gy applications generating emissions reductions and delivering on other sustainable
. Similarly, IAM models have been applied to model the
potential for low energy demand scenarios associated with demand
which assumes information technology innovations such as the internet of things
social changes such as the sharing economy
Nonetheless there are still very i
IAM models and macroeconomic models can integrate ethics, equity
. A key limitation in this context is that, while all countries share the totality of the SDGs,
development priorities differ across countries and over time
to local contexts, and this can only be reflected
An example of a project that assesses the economy
wide impacts of linking sustainable development
with deep decarbonization is the deep decarbonization project or DDPP
